message.content:
There are several verb tenses in English grammar, each indicating different aspects of time:

1. Present Tense: Used to express actions or states that are happening now or are generally true. Examples include "I eat," "She sings," and "They work."
2. Past Tense: Used to describe completed actions or events in the past. Examples include "I ate," "He played," and "We walked."
3. Future Tense: Used to express future actions or predictions. Examples include "I will eat," "She will sing," and "They will play."
4. Progressive Aspect (also known as Continuous Tense): Shows that an action is ongoing or in progress. Examples include "I am eating," "He is running," and "They are walking."
5. Perfect Tense: Indicates a completed action with reference to the present. Examples include "I have eaten," "She has sung," and "They have played."
6. Perfect Continuous (also known as Progressive Perfect): Shows an ongoing or incomplete action that was completed at some point in the past. Examples include "I have been eating," "He has been running," and "They have been playing."
7. Past Perfect Tense: Describes actions that were completed before another past time. Examples include "I had eaten," "She had sung," and "They had played."
8. Future Perfect Tense: Shows an action that will be completed in the future. Examples include "I will have eaten," "He will have sung," and "They will have played."
9. Past Perfect Continuous (also known as the Continuous in the Past): Describes actions that were ongoing before another point in time. Examples include "I had been eating," "She had been running," and "They had been playing."
10. Future Perfect Continuous: Shows an action that will be completed at some future point. Examples include "I will have been eating," "He will have been running," and "They will have been playing."

In addition to these main tenses, there are also conditional forms (used for hypothetical or unlikely situations) and passive voice forms of each tense.
